proposals.reasoning: I’m including myself as leader so my alignment is directly tied to the first result. Bob was an early voice in shaping lineups, so putting him on the mission gives us a strong, immediate alignment check on a key influencer. Henry represents the quieter/mixing-bloc side that several players wanted to see included, which helps avoid just rubber-stamping the initial Alice–Bob–Charlie cluster. This team mixes blocs, tests an early driver of discussion (Bob), and brings in a lower-drama voice (Henry), giving us a clean, informative first read without handing all control to one cluster of players.

votes.comment: Team fits the table’s consensus of mixing blocs (me + Bob as an early driver + quieter Henry). No strong red flags yet, and as a good player I’m comfortable taking an info-rich first mission with myself on it.

I don’t like putting both the leader and a relatively untested quieter player like Henry on the very first team; if it fails, we learn almost nothing about which of them (or Bob) is the problem. I’d rather start with a lineup that avoids that kind of ambiguity.
Good info team: it mixes blocs and includes both Bob and Henry, giving a strong early alignment read on key influencers even if there’s some risk in grouping them.

This matches the mixed-bloc structure many wanted (Alice + one of Bob/Charlie + a quieter/mixing voice). It puts an early driver (Bob) under test without fully handing control to the initial Alice–Bob–Charlie cluster, and we need an info-rich first mission rather than stalling on hypotheticals.
Solid info-gathering lineup that mixes blocs and tests Bob as an early influencer without handing full control to the initial Alice–Bob–Charlie cluster.
Team fits my earlier preference of Alice + one early driver (Bob) + one mixer (Henry); good info gain on Bob without fully rubber-stamping the original Alice–Charlie–Diana lineup.
Henry is evil with me, so this lineup gives us early sabotage potential and information while looking like a reasonable mixed-bloc team.
I like having a mixed-bloc team with myself on it for early info and potential future trust if the mission succeeds.
Team gives evil a seat via Henry while looking reasonable and info-focused for Quest 1.

discussion.content: Early on we’ve got almost no info, so I’d lean toward a team of people who haven’t been pushing too hard to control the discussion—maybe something like me plus two quieter players for the first mission. We just need a clean result to start building reads.

I’m fine with starting simple: Alice plus two people who aren’t trying to steer things too hard yet, maybe something like Charlie and Diana or Frank, just to get a low‑drama first read. I’d avoid stacking the very loud or very quiet extremes on the same team this early.
I’m okay with a low‑drama first team like Alice, me, and Diana—just spread trust a bit and see what happens—while we keep an eye on how Bob and the other strong voices push future teams.

I’m okay with a low‑drama first team, but I don’t love how quickly Alice–Bob–Charlie converged on “Alice + Charlie + me” as the default. I’d rather see at least one of Bob/Frank on the table too, so we’re not just letting the same voices shape both the team and the narrative around it.

I don’t love how fast “Alice + Charlie + Diana” became the consensus either; I’d rather see at least one of Bob/Frank on the first team so we’re testing a slightly different slice of the table instead of letting one bloc set both the lineup and the story around it.

I’m wary of how quickly Alice–Bob–Charlie coalesced around essentially the same lineup, so I’d rather see a first team like Alice + one of (Bob/Charlie) + one of (Diana/Frank) to avoid just rubber‑stamping a single bloc’s preferences.

I like the idea of mixing blocs a bit: something like Alice + one of (Bob/Charlie) + one of (Henry/Frank) feels like it tests both sides without handing the whole narrative to the same cluster of voices.

I’d rather see us keep mixing blocs and bring in some of the quieter folks, so something like Alice + one of (Bob/Charlie) + one of (Henry/Iris) feels like a good info‑gathering first team. It spreads the early trust without just letting the same cluster run the table.

I like the idea of mixing blocs too, but I’d slightly rather see someone like Frank or Henry on with Alice plus one of Bob/Charlie than automatically default to Alice–Charlie–Diana just because it got early momentum. Spreading that first bit of trust across different voices gives us a cleaner read on who’s pushing what later.

proposals.reasoning: This team fits the emerging consensus from discussion: keep Alice from the first mission but avoid repeating the risky Bob–Henry pairing, and add two fresh, relatively untested players. Multiple players (Eve, Frank, Grace) specifically endorsed the quartet of Alice, Charlie, Diana, and Eve as a solid, low-conflict option. It maximizes table agreement, avoids the main points of suspicion from Mission 1, and gives us a cleaner information read on a larger group of new players.

votes.comment: Removes the suspicious Bob–Henry pair while keeping me on the team and tests three new players; best balance of safety and information right now.
Keeps both Bob and Henry off after the 1-fail team and matches the broad table consensus for a relatively safe, informative lineup.
Avoids the risky Bob–Henry pair from the failed mission, includes only one from the original suspect trio, and aligns with broad table consensus for gathering cleaner info.

Matches what I advocated: avoid Bob+Henry together, keep Alice once, and add two fresh players. If it fails, Alice becomes highly suspect; if it passes, we get a strong baseline of likely-good players.

This matches the plan I supported earlier: avoid the Bob–Henry pair, keep Alice for continuity, and add two new players (Charlie, Diana) plus me. If it fails, we get strong info on a large new group; if it passes, we likely isolate the spy among Bob/Henry.

Best info-gathering team so far: keeps exactly one of the suspicious trio (Alice/Bob/Henry) and adds three fresh players, avoiding the risky Bob–Henry combo while still testing Alice. Worth the risk this early.
This is exactly the kind of team I previously endorsed—keeping Alice while avoiding the Bob–Henry pair and adding relatively untested players—so I’ll stay consistent and support it.
This feels too safe and low-info; I’d rather include one of Bob/Henry so we actually narrow down where the first fail came from instead of parking both main suspects off a critical 4-person mission.
All four proposed members are likely good (none are my known evil teammates), so this team is too safe for the resistance and gives us no chance to sabotage.

discussion.content: Since I know I’m good and there was only one FAIL on the first mission, the spy has to be either Bob or Henry, so I’d strongly prefer a team that includes me but avoids putting both of them on together again.

Given the first mission, I’d really like to see a team that keeps Alice but swaps Henry out for a couple of fresh picks like Charlie or Diana. That at least avoids repeating the exact same risk while we gather more info.

I’d rather not see both Bob and Henry on the same team again, but I do want at least one of them included—maybe something like Alice, one of Bob/Henry, plus two fresh picks like me and Diana to spread the risk.

Given the 1-fail result, I really don’t want both Bob and Henry together again—I'd lean toward a team like Alice, me, Charlie, and one of Bob/Henry so we get more info without doubling down on the same risk.
I definitely don’t want to see both Bob and Henry together again—right now I’m most comfortable with a team like Alice, Charlie, Diana, and me, and then we can later test Bob/Henry one at a time.

I’m on board with avoiding Bob and Henry together for now, and I especially like the idea of trying a team like Alice, Charlie, Diana, and Eve this round. If that passes clean, we can start testing Bob and Henry one at a time on later missions.

I agree we shouldn’t put Bob and Henry together again, so I’d be happiest with something like Alice, Charlie, Diana, and either Eve or Iris to keep things mostly in line with what people are already leaning toward while still testing someone new.

Given the single fail, I’m fine staying off this one, but I’d really like to see us keep Alice and add a mix like Charlie, Diana, and either Grace or Iris so we’re spreading info without doubling down on Bob and me together again.

I’m on board with keeping Alice, Charlie, and Diana as a core, and I’d slightly prefer adding me as the fourth so we’re testing someone completely new rather than re-using Bob or Henry while they’re both still under suspicion.

proposals.reasoning: This is exactly the Mission 2 team, which returned a clean success with zero FAIL cards. With the game tied 1–1 and clear suspicion already on the Mission 1 lineup of Alice/Bob/Henry, the safest option is to reuse the only fully successful team we’ve seen so far rather than introduce new uncertainty. Keeping Bob and Henry off the team avoids the direct source of the earlier fail, and adding any new player (Frank, Grace, Iris) would introduce fresh risk with no compensating information advantage at this stage.

votes.comment: Exact repeat of the only fully clean team we’ve seen; safest option while keeping both Bob and Henry (linked to the failed Mission 1) off the mission.
Reusing the only fully clean team we’ve seen (Mission 2) is safest right now, especially keeping both Bob and Henry off after the Mission 1 fail.
Mission 2 with this exact team was clean; keeping Bob and Henry (the Mission 1 fail source) off is safest, and reusing the only proven-success team is best for Good right now.
Repeating the only clean 4-person team we’ve seen is safest; keeping Bob and Henry off after the Mission 1 fail is sensible and there’s no concrete reason yet to distrust anyone in this lineup.
Same team as the clean Mission 2 success and excludes both Bob and Henry from the failed Mission 1, so this is currently the safest option.
Reusing the only fully successful team is safest; keeping both Bob and Henry (source of the Mission 1 fail) off the mission is better than introducing a new, untested player.

I don’t like treating the Mission 2 lineup as auto-clear after a single success; reusing it gives us no new information and could just hide a coordinated spy, so I’d rather see at least one new person swapped in.
No suspected evils are on this team; as it stands, it’s too likely to succeed and give good a strong edge.
All four are widely townread and Mission 2 already showed this lineup can succeed; as evil I need a chance to get one of my teammates onto a mission.

discussion.content: Given Mission 1 failed and I know I’m good, I don’t want Bob or Henry on this team at all; I’d feel best sending something like Charlie, Diana, Eve, and one of Frank/Grace/Iris.

I’m fine staying off this one given Mission 1, but from what we’ve seen I’d really like to keep Henry (and honestly Iris too, at least for now) off the team and stick with something like Alice/Charlie/Diana/Eve plus one of Frank or Grace next time.

Given Mission 2 was clean with zero fails, I’d really like to keep that exact core of Alice/Charlie/Diana/Eve together for this one. I’m especially wary of adding Bob or Henry back in until we get more info from later missions.

I really like keeping the Mission 2 core of Alice/Charlie/me/Eve together since it came back clean, and I’d rather fill the fourth slot from Frank or Grace than risk bringing Bob or Henry back in right now.

I’m very happy sticking with the Mission 2 core of Alice/Charlie/Diana/me for this one, and I’d really prefer to keep both Bob and Henry off teams until we get something that clears up that Mission 1 fail.

I’m very happy with keeping the Mission 2 core of Alice/Charlie/Diana/Eve together, and if we need a fourth, I think it’s much safer to pull from me or Grace rather than risk putting Bob or Henry back on a team right now.

Sticking with the clean Mission 2 core of Alice/Charlie/Diana/Eve makes the most sense to me, and if we need a fourth I’d much rather see it come from Frank or me than risk bringing Bob or Henry back in right now.

Given the Mission 1 fail I get why folks don’t want me or Bob on this one, but I’d be careful about treating the Mission 2 team as “confirmed good” off a single success. I’d keep that core for now, but if we’re adding a fourth I slightly prefer pulling from Iris or Grace so we’re not just locking in the same voices every time.

I’m a little uneasy treating the Mission 2 team as auto-clear when Alice was also on the failed Mission 1, so I’d rather see something like Charlie/Diana/Eve plus one of Frank, Grace, or me this round.

proposals.reasoning: The only failed mission was Mission 1 with Bob and Henry, while Missions 2 and 3 using the core of Alice, Charlie, Diana, and Eve were both clean (0 FAILs). That strongly suggests the safest assumption is that the A/C/D/E core is good or at least majority-good. For the fifth slot, adding Grace keeps us away from the Bob/Henry fail pool and matches the broad table consensus to prefer Grace over Frank or Iris this round. This team maximizes our chances of a clean success while minimizing exposure to the only demonstrated source of a fail.

votes.comment: Core of Alice/Charlie/Diana/Eve is double-proven clean; only fail implicated Bob/Henry, and Grace is outside that pool, so this is the safest high-probability success team.
Core of Alice/Charlie/Diana/Eve has two clean missions and the only known evils (from the fail pattern) are off the team; Grace is the safest fifth among the remaining options.
The A/C/D/E core is double‑clean and the only fail is from the Bob/Henry pool; adding Grace avoids that risk and is the safest high‑probability team.
Sticking with the double-clean A/C/D/E core and avoiding the Bob/Henry fail pool makes sense; adding Grace is the safest extension given current info.
Keeps the twice-clean core of Alice/Charlie/Diana/Eve and avoids the Bob/Henry fail pool; Grace is as safe an addition as we can get right now.
Double-clean A/C/D/E core plus Grace avoiding the Bob/Henry fail pool is statistically the safest; as good, I’m fine staying off if this maximizes win odds.
If this team is clean, good wins the game; as evil and the only likely suspect on it, I need to keep this from going through.
Keeps the proven clean core while still including an evil (Grace), giving us the option to sabotage this crucial mission.
Grace (known evil) is on a team otherwise widely trusted, giving us a strong chance to sabotage without suspicion.

discussion.content: Given that the only fail was on Mission 1 with Bob and Henry, I’m happiest reusing the Mission 2/3 core of me, Charlie, Diana, and Eve, and adding one of Grace/Frank/Iris rather than Bob or Henry.

I like sticking with the M2/M3 core of Alice, Charlie, Diana, and Eve since it’s clean twice in a row, and I’d rather add Grace or Frank than Iris or Henry given where the only fail came from. If we keep that pattern, evil has to gamble pretty hard to stop us.

I’m good sticking with the M2/M3 core of Alice, me, Diana, and Eve since it’s cleared twice, and for the fifth I’d rather try Grace or Frank than go back to Bob or Henry where the only fail came from. Iris is a bit of an unknown for me, so I’d prefer we leave her off this one too.

I’m very happy keeping the M2/M3 core of Alice, Charlie, me, and Eve since it’s double‑clean; for the fifth, I slightly prefer Grace over Frank just based on vibes so far, but I’m fine with either as long as we stay away from Bob/Henry this round.
I definitely want to keep the proven core of Alice, Charlie, Diana, and me together, and for the fifth I lean Grace over Frank just to stay as far away as possible from the Bob/Henry fail pool.

I’m on board locking in the Alice/Charlie/Diana/Eve core again, but from my perspective I’d really like us to test me over Grace this round so we don’t end up going into the last mission with zero info on my alignment.

I’m happy sticking with the Alice/Charlie/Diana/Eve core again since it’s the only thing that’s been consistently clean, and between the remaining options I slightly prefer adding myself over Frank just so we’re not introducing anyone from the Bob/Henry side of the pool. If people really want to “test” someone new, though, I’d still rather it be me than risk pulling from where the only fail came from.

Given that the only fail came from the Bob/Henry pool, I really don’t think it makes sense to touch that again, so I’m fully behind the Alice/Charlie/Diana/Eve core plus Grace as the safest combo right now. If we start swapping in Frank or Iris here, we’re just adding uncertainty to what should be our cleanest shot.

I’m fine staying off this one and keeping the Alice/Charlie/Diana/Eve core, and between the options I’d rather we add Grace than Frank or dip back into the Bob/Henry pool where the only fail came from. If this team is clean, we’ll have a really strong info baseline going into a potential last mission.

proposals.reasoning: Missions 2 and 3 with the core Alice–Charlie–Diana–Eve both succeeded with 0 FAILs, which makes that quartet our most reliable data-backed block. Mission 4 swapped in Grace as the only new member and immediately produced a fail, heavily implicating Grace rather than the established core. Mission 1’s fail points to at least one evil among Alice/Bob/Henry, but given Alice’s presence on two clean missions and how strongly several players are now pushing to exclude her, I read Alice as more likely framed than genuinely evil. Bob and Henry only appear on the first failed mission and bring extra risk, so I keep them off. Grace is the sole new factor on the second fail and therefore stays off as well. Between the untested options Frank and Iris, I choose Frank as the fifth since we must add someone outside the fail-heavy Alice/Bob/Henry/Grace cluster, and including exactly one unproven player with the proven core seems safer than rebuilding around two untested players. This team maximizes use of the only repeatedly clean configuration we have while isolating the most directly implicated suspects.

votes.comment: Core Alice/Charlie/Diana/Eve has two clean missions; Grace is the only new factor on the second fail and looks most suspicious, while the strong push to exclude Alice feels coordinated. Adding just one untested player (Frank) to the proven core seems safer than rebuilding around multiple unproven players.

Uses the only fully clean core (Alice/Charlie/Diana/Eve) and swaps out the clearly suspicious Grace for the still-untested Frank, avoiding both Bob/Henry and the need to gamble on two new players at once.

Alice–Charlie–Diana–Eve is our only twice-proven clean core; the Mission 4 fail is best explained by Grace, so reusing that core and adding a single new player (Frank) is safer than rebuilding around two untested players.

Both failed missions included Alice, and we have a clean track record with the Charlie/Diana/Eve core. I’d rather avoid the Alice/Bob/Henry/Grace cluster entirely and push for Charlie–Diana–Eve–Frank–Iris instead.

Charlie/Diana/Eve are highly trusted from two clean missions; Grace is the only new addition on the second fail, so she’s most suspect. The M1 fail implicates the Alice/Bob/Henry cluster, but Alice being on two clean missions makes Bob/Henry more suspicious than her. This team uses the proven core, avoids Bob/Henry/Grace, and adds just one untested player (Frank), which is a reasonable final risk.

Two clean missions with Alice–Charlie–Diana–Eve strongly suggest that core is good and that Mission 4’s fail most likely came from Grace. The simplest fit is Bob/Henry/Grace as evil, which makes this team all-good aside from me, and I know I’m good, so I’ll back this lineup.
I still don’t like sending Alice here when both fails sit in that Alice/Bob/Henry/Grace cluster; I’d rather stick with the Charlie/Diana/Eve core and add Frank and Iris instead.

If both fails sit in the Alice/Bob/Henry/Grace orbit, I don’t love sending Alice again on the decider—especially when we have a Charlie/Diana/Eve/Frank/Iris alternative that avoids repeating anyone from the suspicious cluster.
I still don’t want Alice back on the decider when both fails sit in the Alice/Bob/Henry/Grace cluster; I’d rather run Charlie–Diana–Eve–Frank–Iris instead of reintroducing that risk.

discussion.content: Given the patterns, I think our safest core is still Alice/Charlie/Diana/Eve, and we should add someone who hasn’t touched a failed mission yet—Frank or Iris—while keeping Bob, Henry, and especially Grace off this last team.
I’d stick with the proven Mission 2/3 core of Alice/Charlie/Diana/Eve and add Frank as the fifth—bringing in Iris or Henry on the decider feels like a bigger gamble than we need.

I’m confident Grace is the common denominator on the only new fail, so she has to stay off, and given both fails involved Alice, I’d leave her out too. I like sticking with the clean Charlie/Diana/Eve core and adding Frank and Iris for the last team.
I still trust the Alice/Charlie/Diana/Eve core from the two clean missions, and Grace is the only new factor on the last fail, so I’d keep Bob, Henry, and Grace off and add Frank as the fifth.
I’m most comfortable treating Charlie/Diana/Eve as a lock and keeping Grace, Bob, and Henry off, so I’d run Alice–Charlie–Diana–Eve plus Frank for this last mission.
I think Charlie/Diana/Eve are our safest core, and with both fails pointing toward the Alice/Bob/Henry/Grace cluster, I’d run Charlie–Diana–Eve–Frank–Iris for the last mission.

From my perspective, Charlie/Diana/Eve look like the safest core, and after that last fail I’m really not comfortable sending Alice again. I’d back a Charlie–Diana–Eve–Frank–Iris team for this final mission.

Given both fails sit in the Alice/Bob/Henry/Grace orbit, I’m most comfortable locking in Charlie/Diana/Eve and rounding it out with Frank and Iris. I’d really rather not risk sending Alice again on the decider.

I’m with the group that sees Charlie/Diana/Eve as the safest lock, and given how both fails cluster around the Alice/Bob/Henry/Grace side, I think rounding that core out with Frank and me is the lowest-risk option. If we avoid repeating the Alice/Bob/Henry/Grace suspects, we at least minimize the chances of another hidden saboteur slipping in.

evil_discussion.content: I’m leaning pretty hard toward Eve as Merlin: she consistently locked onto Bob and Henry as the fail pool early, quietly kept Iris off the “proven core,” but then on Mission 5 very cleanly carved out a team that excluded all three evils (Henry, Iris, and me) without overexplaining why. Alice gets some points for pushing Bob/Henry as the M1 fail pair, but her late, almost-theoretical pivot onto me feels more like good-town pattern reading, whereas Eve’s path looks like someone who knew exactly where not to step the whole game.

I’m mostly with Grace that Eve is the likeliest Merlin: from very early on she was laser-focused on quarantining the Bob/Henry pool, then later cleanly boxed out all three of us (me, Grace, Iris) on M5 without needing to “solve” out loud in a way that would draw heat. Alice’s trajectory feels more like sharp town re-evaluating patterns (she kept sending herself into risky spots and only later shaded Grace), whereas Eve consistently shepherded the table toward exactly‑one‑evil or zero‑evil teams while keeping her reasoning framed as “safest core” vibes rather than hard, risky reads.

I’m with you both that Eve is the best Merlin hit: from Mission 2 on she keeps hard-quarantining the Bob/Henry pool, quietly treats Alice/Charlie/Diana as a “safe” spine, and by Mission 5 she’s surgically cut all three of us (me, Grace, Henry) without ever needing to spell out a full solve. Alice looks sharp but more iterative—she keeps putting herself on risky teams and only gradually shifts suspicion onto Grace—whereas Eve’s path looks like someone who already knew exactly where the mines were and just sold it as conservative, “safest core” logic.

assassin_phase.reasoning: Eve consistently pushed to isolate the Bob/Henry pool after the first fail and then quietly treated Alice/Charlie/Diana as a safe core without needing to justify it with strong, explicit reads. By Mission 5 she cleanly excluded all three evils (Grace, Henry, and me) while framing it as a conservative, “safest core” choice rather than a hard solve, which strongly suggests hidden knowledge consistent with Merlin.
